intro: Sida neomexicana, commonly known as New Mexico mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, such as deserts and rocky soils. The plant features palmate leaves with five to seven lobes and produces small, pale yellow flowers that bloom in clusters. It is part of the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its fibrous, woody stems. Sida neomexicana is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
